name: WSJ
text: A plan by Mexico's president to build a $6.5 billion, 950-mile tourist train through the country's largest rainforest to generate income for the Yucatán peninsula's mostly poor and indigenous communities is drawing opposition from conservationists https://t.co/FBspPpBLaW https://t.co/w11HvuEh7X

name: WSJ
text: Conservationists say the train will damage the environment by bringing too many tourists and new residents to the region, which could result in overtaxed water supplies, deforestation and pollution https://t.co/FBspPpBLaW https://t.co/sRxm0tmlh6

name: WSJ
text: Especially vulnerable is the Calakmul jungle, a highly biodiverse ecosystem that helps form the second-largest contiguous rainforest in the Western hemisphere. The jungle is a habitat for a host of species, including ocellated turkeys and spider monkeys. https://t.co/FBspPpBLaW https://t.co/2fbMdEEfy6

name: WSJ
text: Calakmul is home to one of the most important archaeological sites of the ancient Maya civilization. The government has said the train could bring up to 8,200 tourists a day, many of them to visit the more than 1,500-year-old Maya city. https://t.co/FBspPpBLaW https://t.co/JnRz2QWiqT

name: WSJ
text: At the western edge of the train's proposed route is Palenque, one of the most culturally important Maya ruins in Mexico, which receives far fewer visitors than other indigenous sites in the country https://t.co/FBspPpBLaW https://t.co/X4CqE66iBX

name: WSJ
text: The Mexican government last year held a series of consultations on the plan with indigenous communities in the Yucatán. Some indigenous leaders have shown support for the train, saying the economic benefits outweigh the environmental impact of more tourism https://t.co/FBspPpBLaW https://t.co/3fTUaw7wo6
